Nubbing Lists in (consteval) C++

2023/07/23
This article was written by an AI ðŸ¤–. The original article can be found here.

In this article, the author explores the task of eliminating duplicate list elements in C++ at compile-time. The author starts by explaining the complexity of the task, as the lists are represented as tuples and the elements might have different types. The goal is to create a function that takes a tuple as input and returns a tuple with duplicate elements removed.

The author begins by providing a helper function for comparing elements of different types. They then present their first attempt at solving the problem using recursion and variadic packs. However, this approach doesn't work as expected, resulting in numerous lines of errors.

To overcome this limitation, the author suggests using non-type template parameters to pass constexpr values as template arguments. They demonstrate how to implement this approach and discuss the error messages provided by different compilers.

The article concludes by acknowledging that the standard might be interpreted differently by different compilers. However, the author suggests that rolling their own tuple implementation could be a potential solution.

This article provides valuable insights into the challenges of eliminating duplicate list elements in C++ at compile-time. Developers interested in modern metaprogramming and template metaprogramming will find this article informative and thought-provoking.
